title: Quiz 5: NCK Paper One - August 2011
description: Examination for Admission to the Register of Community Health Nurses (Basic) - August 2011. Covers Medical-Surgical, Pharmacology, and Nursing Fundamentals.

questions.question: The cycle in which bile salts and other substances excreted by the liver are absorbed by the intestinal mucosa and returned to the liver via the portal circulation is:
questions.explanation: Enterohepatic circulation describes the recycling process where bile acids are excreted into the intestine, absorbed, and returned to the liver.

questions.question: Gram negative bacilli include:
questions.explanation: E. coli, Salmonella, and Shigella are all gram-negative rods (bacilli). Staph and Strep are gram-positive cocci.
questions.hint: Look for the group with NO cocci.

questions.question: Complications of asthma include:

options.text: Left sided heart failure, ruptured bleb.

questions.explanation: Long-standing asthma can lead to airway remodeling similar to COPD (Chronic Bronchitis/Emphysema). Ruptured blebs (pneumothorax) can also occur in acute attacks.

questions.question: When performing postural drainage for the lower lobes of the lung, the correct position is:

options.text: Dorsal position with a pillow supporting the waist.
Lateral position with the head elevated.

questions.explanation: To drain the lower lobes, the head must be lower than the chest (Trendelenburg) so gravity assists drainage towards the trachea.
questions.hint: Gravity must pull secretions 'up' to the trachea.

questions.question: The aura stage of a tonic clonic seizure is characterized by:

options.text: Visual disturbance, tingling sensations, change in mood.
Auditory sensation, change in mood, loss of consciousness.
Tonic contractions, temporary cessation of breathing.

questions.explanation: An aura is a warning sign (visual/sensory/mood) experienced before the loss of consciousness and seizure activity.
questions.hint: A warning sign before the seizure hits.

questions.question: Clinical manifestations of hypoparathyroidism include:
questions.explanation: Hypoparathyroidism causes Hypocalcemia, leading to neuromuscular irritability, tetany, and dangerous laryngeal spasms.

questions.question: Management of impetigo involves:
questions.explanation: Impetigo is a bacterial infection treated with antibiotics. Steroids worsen infection; antifungals treat fungus.
questions.hint: It is a bacterial skin infection.

questions.question: When caring for a patient with a perineal wound, the nurse should:

options.text: Care for the patient in a dorsal recumbent position.
Administer analgesic before irrigating the wound.

questions.explanation: Perineal wounds are very painful. Analgesia prior to care/irrigation is the priority for patient comfort and compliance.

questions.question: The main purpose of jejunojejunostomy in gastric resection is to:

options.text: Prevent reflux of bile and pancreatic fluids into the oesophagus.

questions.explanation: This procedure diverts bile away from the stomach remnant to prevent alkaline reflux gastritis/esophagitis.

questions.question: A nephrostomy drainage is usually inserted in the:
questions.explanation: Nephrostomy is a tube placed directly into the renal pelvis of the kidney to drain urine.
questions.hint: Directly into the kidney's collecting basin.

questions.question: Transurethral incision of the prostate (TUIP) is indicated in management of:

options.text: Initial stages of benign prostatic hypertrophy (Small prostate).

questions.explanation: TUIP is for smaller prostates (<30g) to improve flow without removing tissue (like TURP).
questions.hint: Less invasive than TURP, for smaller glands.

questions.question: Risk factors of osteoporosis include:
questions.explanation: Alcohol inhibits bone formation. Early menopause removes protective estrogen early.
questions.hint: Estrogen protects bone; alcohol hurts it.

questions.question: In rheumatoid arthritis, inflammation of the joints begins in the:
questions.explanation: RA typically affects small joints (hands, feet, wrists) symmetrically first.

questions.question: The main aim of escharotomy in treatment of full thickness burns is to:

options.text: Allow underlying viable tissues to expand.

questions.explanation: Escharotomy releases the rigid burn scab (eschar) to relieve pressure and allow circulation/expansion, preventing compartment syndrome.

questions.question: Characteristics of 1st degree burns include:
questions.explanation: 1st degree (superficial) burns appear red (erythema), painful, and dry without blisters.

questions.question: In simple mastectomy:

options.text: Pectoralis major muscle and the entire breast is excised.
Axillary lymph nodes and pectoralis major muscles are left intact.
Underlying chest muscles and chain of internal mammary lymph nodes are removed.
Entire breast and axillary lymph nodes are removed.

questions.explanation: Simple mastectomy removes only breast tissue/nipple. Radical mastectomy removes nodes and muscles.

questions.question: When performing gastric lavage, the nurse should:

options.text: Place the patient in the left lateral position.
Use a 50cc syringe to push fluid forcibly.

questions.explanation: Left lateral decubitus position minimizes the risk of aspiration if the patient vomits.

questions.question: Reed-sternberg cell is a pathologic hallmark essential in diagnosis of:
questions.explanation: Reed-Sternberg cells are the definitive diagnostic finding for Hodgkin's Lymphoma.

questions.question: Match the ear condition with its characteristic:
questions.explanation: Otosclerosis involves bone hardening causing conductive loss. Meniere's involves fluid imbalance causing vertigo.

questions.question: Intracapsular extraction of the lens is currently the most commonly used method for cataract management.
questions.explanation: Extracapsular extraction (ECCE) or Phacoemulsification is standard to preserve the posterior capsule for lens implantation. Intracapsular is rarely used now.
questions.hint: Modern surgery leaves the capsule behind.

questions.question: Select the nursing roles for a patient on Opioid Analgesics:

options.text: Monitor for constipation and encourage fluids.
Ensure safety (Bed rails up) due to sedation.
Re-assess pain level 30 mins after administration.

questions.explanation: Opioids cause respiratory depression, constipation, and sedation/dizziness.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical manifestations of Cardiac Tamponade (Beck's Triad)?
questions.explanation: Beck's Triad: Low BP, Muffled Sounds, JVD. Pulsus Paradoxus is also a sign.
questions.hint: Heart is compressed: Low flow, quiet sounds, backed up veins.

questions.question: Order the steps of the physiological process of respiration:
questions.explanation: Air enters lungs -> Gas exchange in lungs -> Transport -> Gas exchange at tissues.

questions.question: Match the Blood Product with its indication:

richContent.content:
ProductDescription
Whole BloodContains all components
PRBCConcentrated RBCs
FFPPlasma with clotting factors

questions.explanation: Whole blood for volume+cells; PRBCs for O2 carrying; FFP for clotting factors; Platelets for clotting cells.
questions.hint: Match the deficit to the replacement.

questions.question: What nursing interventions are appropriate for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)?
questions.explanation: Semi-Fowler's localizes infection. Heat (not cold) is usually used for pain. Rest conserves energy.

questions.question: Select nursing diagnoses applicable to a Compound Femur Fracture:

options.text: Risk for Infection related to open wound.
Impaired Gas Exchange related to fracture.

questions.explanation: Compound fractures have high infection risk (bone exposed) and bleeding risk.
questions.hint: Compound means the skin is broken.

questions.question: How can a nurse establish rapport with a client?
questions.explanation: Rapport builds on trust, empathy, and respect, not authority.

questions.question: Name the hard outer covering of the crown of a tooth.
questions.explanation: Enamel is the hardest substance in the human body, covering the tooth crown.
questions.hint: The hardest substance in the body.

questions.question: Case Study: Mrs. M has a new Colostomy. What are correct care steps?

richContent.content:
Case: Colostomy Care

Mrs. M is post-op day 2 following colon cancer surgery with a new stoma.

options.text: Measure stoma size for appliance fit.

questions.explanation: Stoma viability (Color) is priority. Fluids should be encouraged (unless contraindicated) to prevent constipation. Body image is a major psychosocial concern.

questions.question: Case Study: Master Ko (10y) has Acute Glomerulonephritis. Which findings and interventions apply?

richContent.content:
Case: Acute Glomerulonephritis

Master Ko presents with edema and dark urine following a throat infection.

questions.explanation: Glomerulonephritis causes Hematuria, Edema, and Hypertension. Management involves Rest, Low Sodium diet, and Fluid restriction.
